Title: "Working with Literal Values and Operators in Expressions"
Text:
C:\Users\adamh\Downloads\azure-search.pdfSkill inputs can take literal values as their inputs instead of dynamic values queried fromthe existing document. This can be achieved by prefixing the value with an equal sign.Values can be numbers, strings or Boolean. String values can be enclosed in single ' ordouble " quotes.ExpressionValue=4242Enumerating arrays in contextLiteral valuesExpressionValue=2.
45E-40.000245="some string""some string"='some other string'"some other string"="unicod\u0065""unicode"=falsefalseIt's possible to combine values together using unary, binary and ternary operators.Operators can combine literal values and values resulting from path evaluation. Whenused inside an expression, paths should be enclosed between "$(" and ")".
ExpressionValue=!falsetrueExpressionValue=-42-42=-$(/document/merged_content/entities/0/offset)-9ExpressionValue=2+24=2+$(/document/merged_content/entities/0/offset)11Composite expressionsBoolean not '!'Negative '-'Addition '+'Subtraction '-'ExpressionValueExpressionValue=2-11=$(/document/merged_content/entities/0/offset)-27ExpressionValue=2*36=$(/document/merged_content/entities/0/offset)*218ExpressionValue=3/21.
5=$(/document/merged_content/entities/0/offset)/33ExpressionValue=15%43=$(/document/merged_content/entities/0/offset)%21ExpressionValue=15<4false=4<=4true=15>4true=1>=2falseMultiplication '*'Division '/'Modulo '%'Less than, less than or equal, greater than and greaterthan or equal '<' '<=' '>' '>='ExpressionValue=15==4false=4==4true=15! =4true=1!=1falseExpressionValue=true&&truetrue=true&&falsefalse=true||truetrue=true||falsetrue=false||falsefalse=true^falsetrue=true^truefalseIt is possible to give an input different values based on the evaluation of a Booleanexpression using the ternary operator.
